title: HW4 Q6
content: Context: This coding problem explores the important concept of inductive bias in CNNs. If you are unfamiliar with the term, inductive bias refers to assumptions about the input data that when satisfied, enable CNNs to work more effectively, i.e. locality (pixels closer to eachother are more correlated) and translation invariance. In the problem, you will investigate patterns learned by filters and how they evolve during training in different scenarios.
document: Context: This coding problem explores the important concept of inductive bias in CNNs. If you are unfamiliar with the term, inductive bias refers to assumptions about the input data that when satisfied, enable CNNs to work more effectively, i.e. locality (pixels closer to eachother are more correlated) and translation invariance. In the problem, you will investigate patterns learned by filters and how they evolve during training in different scenarios.

comments.content: This is the graph I get for Q2. It mostly matches what the notebook expects, except CNN universally outperforms MLP, when there is supposed to be an exception to that trend. Did anyone else get this result?
comments.document: This is the graph I get for Q2. It mostly matches what the notebook expects, except CNN universally outperforms MLP, when there is supposed to be an exception to that trend. Did anyone else get this result?

comments.content: Additionally, on the third question we are asked to compare "learned", "untrainable", and "edge-detector" kernels. I assume "learned" and "untrainable" mean the "trained" and "untrained" kernels, but I am not seeing any "edge-detector" kernels. I'm not sure if I'm overlooking an obvious mistake or not. Do the 3 square "subsections" of the printed kernels correspond to the three sections, perhaps?
comments.document: Additionally, on the third question we are asked to compare "learned", "untrainable", and "edge-detector" kernels. I assume "learned" and "untrainable" mean the "trained" and "untrained" kernels, but I am not seeing any "edge-detector" kernels. I'm not sure if I'm overlooking an obvious mistake or not. Do the 3 square "subsections" of the printed kernels correspond to the three sections, perhaps?

comments.content: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>I think among the trained kernels, the left & middle kernels are likely the edge detector kernels (one for horizontal and one for vertical) according to how the stripe patterns look like.</paragraph><paragraph/></document>
comments.document: I think among the trained kernels, the left & middle kernels are likely the edge detector kernels (one for horizontal and one for vertical) according to how the stripe patterns look like.

comments.content: For Qn2(ii), why I get this graph shows performance of CNN initialized with edge detectors is better than CNN initialized with random weights？
comments.document: For Qn2(ii), why I get this graph shows performance of CNN initialized with edge detectors is better than CNN initialized with random weights？

comments.content: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>I think for a low data regime, the strong inductive bias of edge detectors provides high-quality features immediately. Random weights outperform edge detectors only in a very high data regime.</paragraph></document>
comments.document: I think for a low data regime, the strong inductive bias of edge detectors provides high-quality features immediately. Random weights outperform edge detectors only in a very high data regime.
